title-group.article-title: Effect of Damages on Crack-visible of the Cavity Opening Displacement in Burning Solid Fuel

article-meta.aff: Department Strength of Materials, Azerbaijan Technical University, 25, Hussein Javid Avenue, Baku AZ 1073, Azerbaijan Republic

abstract.p: The problem of the mechanics of fracture of the medium weakened by crack-visible cavity, whose surfaces burns, is considered. It is considered that in the vicinity of technological defect (crack-visible cavity), there are zones with the interparticle bonds in the material. It has been investigated for the quasi-static process of deformation of burning fuel. Determination of the unknown parameters describing crack-visible cavity opening displacement is reduced to the solution of a system of singular integral equations, from the solution of which the tractions in the bonds are found. The sufficient condition of stability of a mode ‘burning-fracture’ is received.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Sometimes, fracture of burning solid fuel is the cause of transition of engine’s operation to unsteady mode that leads to explosion. The most extended cause of engine transition to off-design condition is the availability of crack-visible defects in fuel that may reduce to unsteady burning. When burning front approaches the edge of such a crack-visible cavity, the burning covers all crack-visible cavities because of high pressure in the combustion chamber. In connection with requirements of up-to-date engineering, in particular solid fuel installations with steadily increasing requirements to strength, reliability, and efficiency of designed systems, there arises the necessity to improve ways for simulation and development of new design methods that more completely and adequately consider the mechanical properties of materials.

sec.title: FORMULATION OF THE PROBLEM
sec.p:
In order to increase the safe operation of engine on trajectory, we consider local fracture of body weakened by a crack-visible cavity whose surface burns. It is assumed that all reagents of the fuel are uniformly distributed in solid phase and combustion reaction products are gaseous. We consider the times that are small in comparison with typical relaxation time of stresses in fuel, and with typical time of fuel heating because of heat conductivity. On the basis of this assumption, we can assume that the fuel is brittle and its temperature is constant. We study the quasi-static process of fuel deformation whose cross-section in the plane x+iy occupies a circle (Figure 1). We use a model of a crack with bonds between the lips in end areas that provides experimental verification (Ji and de Genes, 1993; Cox and Marshall, 1994; Budianscky et al., 1995; Goldstein et al., 1997; Haj-Ali, 2009; Truong and Kitamura, 2010) for composite materials with polymeric binder when adhesion strength is less than the strength of polymers. In this case, adhesive forces (bonds) and high elastic deformations will be concentrated in a narrow area; as it is easy to be convinced, this is unessential within blow-up solutions of theory of small elastic deformations. Mixed rocket fuel usually consists of crystallic particles arranged in polymeric binder. We consider a model of a crack with adhesion (bonding) forces that are continuously distributed in the narrow end area of a crack (domain D) and have the given deformation diagram. Moreover, the size of this domain is not known in advance. Everywhere in sequel, the boundary conditions from the surface of crack-visible cavity and domain D are taken to the plane y1=0 (Figure 1). By 2 h, we denote the thickness of a cavity unknown in advance, by 2υ the mutual shift of opposite walls of crack-visible cavity, and by hc the thickness of the burnt layer on one wall. All these quantities are some desired functions x1 and t. They are connected between themselves in the following way; h=hc+υ. Figure 1.
Calculation scheme of fracture mechanics problem for burning body.
Let, on a contour of solid fuel occupying the domain in the form of circle with radius R, only normal displacement ur(θ) and tangential component of the surface force Nθ(θ) be given.
In plane Oxy, the crack-visible cavity with end domains is represented with a cut of length 2l1 along the axis x1, and thickness of the cut is h<<l1 (Figure 1).

Pre-fracture zones will arise in proportion to the loading of the fuel during the operation of the engine and these zones are modeled as domains in which the interparticle bonds of the material have been weakened. The interaction of the surfaces of these domains is modeled by the introduction of a pre-fracture zone of the bonds, which have a specified deformation pattern, between the crack faces. The physical nature of these and the sizes of pre-fracture zones depend on the form of the material. Since the above-mentioned zones (inter-layers of overstressed material) are small in comparison with the remaining part of the fuel, they can be conceptually eliminated by replacing them with cuts, the surfaces which interact one another according to a certain law that corresponds to the action of the material which has been removed. Taking into account of these effects in fracture mechanics is an important but an exceedingly difficult problem. Investigations (Panasyuk, 1991; Ji and de Genes, 1993; Cox and Marshall, 1994; Budianscky et al., 1995; Goldstein et al., 1997; Haj-Ali, 2009; Truong and Kitamura, 2010) of the occurrence of domains with a disrupted structure of the material show that, during the initial stage, the pre-fracture zones have the form of a narrow elongated layer. The interaction of pre-fracture zones in vicinity of crack-visible cavity whose surface burns may reduce to pressure increase in fuel, stability loss of burning crack, appearance of new crack-visible cavities, and explosion.

Let, in solid fuel in the vicinity of crack-visible cavity, there be (N-1) pre-fracture zones of length 2lk(k=2,…,N) (Figure 1). At the centers of pre-fracture zones, we arrange an origin of coordinates xkOkyk, whose axis xk coincide with pre-fracture zone and make angles αk with the axis x (Figure 1). As the fuel is loaded, in bonds connecting the lips of pre-fracture zones and crack-visible cavity at the end zones, normal qyk(xk) and tangential qxkyk(xk) tractions (k=1,2,…,N), respectively will arise. The quantities of these stresses and sizes of the pre-fracture zones and end domains of crack-visible cavity are not known in advance. On the basis of what has been said, the normal and tangential forces that numerically equal to qyk(xk) and qxkyk(xk), respectively, will be applied to the lips of pre-fracture zones and crack-visible cavity at end zones.
Boundary conditions in the considered problem are of the form (1) (2) (3) where p(x1) is gas pressure intensity in cavity and Lk the faces of the k-th pre-fracture zone.

For closeness, the basic relations of the problem should be completed with gas dynamics equations and with equations connecting openings of pre-fracture zones faces and end domains of cavity and the bond tractions.

Equations of gas flow in crack-visible cavity for a plane stationary case are of the form (Cherepanov, 1979) (4)
here p0,ρ0 and p1,ρ1 are pressure and density of gas in combustion chamber for x1=0 and at the end of cavity; h0(x1) the given thickness of initial cavity; Vx the gas velocity, χ the adiabatic exponent; ρs the density of solid phase; and f(p) some function which characterizes the burning rate, assumed to be given.

We can represent the equations connecting the openings of end zone face cavity and pre-fracture zones, and the bond tractions in the form (Mirsalimov, 2007) (5) where the functions C(xk,σk) are considered as the effective compliance of the bonds which depends on their tension; σk=qyk2+qxkyk2 the modulus of the vector of the bond tractions, (υk+-υk-) the normal, and (uk+-uk-) the tangential component of the expansion of the pre-fracture zone and end domains of crack-visible cavity.

sec.title: THE METHOD OF THE BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEM SOLUTION
sec.p: By S+, we denote a domain occupied by fuel, and bounded by a circle L0 and one rectilinear section L1=[-l1,l1]. The domain to be completed to complete complex plane is denoted by S-.

Under accepted assumptions, the problem is reduced (Muskhelishvili, 1977) to the definition of two analytical functions of complex variables Φ(z) and Ψ(z), satisfying the following boundary conditions: (6) (7) (8) where (9)
Fk=qyk(xk)-iqxkyk(xk) (k=2,…,N); t is the affix of the points of the contour L0; k0=3-4ν;andν the Poisson’s ratio of the material and μ the shear modulus.

On the circle L0, in general case, we take the functions fr(t) and Nθ(t) in the form of Fourier series: (10) where Vν,Tν(ν=0,±1,±2,…) are generally speaking, known complex coefficients and are determined by the formulae
Passing in relations (6) and (7) to conjugated values, after some transformations on the contour L0 we get the boundary conditions in the form (11) (12)
On the basis of (11) and (12), on the circle L0 we will have the following relation (k0-1)[Φ(t)+Φ(t)¯]+2t2R2[R2tΦ'(t)+Ψ(t)]=2[2μfr'(t)+iNθ(t)]onL0
Inserting the relation (10) into the last equality we arrive at the following result: (13)
Introduce, on L0, a new unknown auxiliary function ω(t)∈H (the Hölder condition) in the form: (14)
Summing up relations (13) and (14), we have (15)
Substituting (15) in (14), one obtains (16) where (17) (18a) (18b)
On the basis of the theorem on analytic continuation and properties of Cauchy type integral, from relations (15) and (16), we have: (19) (20)
In relations (19), (20), the functions Φ*(z) and Ψ*(z) are analytic in complete complex plane cut along the sections Lk=[-lk,lk](k=1,2,…,N) and vanish at infinity, i.e., Φ*(∞)=0, Ψ*(∞)=0.
We will look up for the auxiliary unknown function ω(t)∈H on L0 in the form of Fourier series (21) where αν(ν=0,±1,±2,…) are the unknown complex coefficients.
Substituting relation (21) to the first formulae of (19) and (20) and using the Cauchy integral theorem, we get the general formulae for the desired functions: (22)
Here (23a) (23b) We will seek the functions Φ*(z) and Ψ*(z)in the form (Savruk, 1981; Mirsalimov, 1984) (24)
Here, gk(xk) are the desired functions, which characterize the opening of displacements of crack-visible cavity faces with end domains and pre-fracture zones (25)

The boundary conditions on the segments gk(xk) help to define the unknown functions yk=0,-lk≤xk≤lk(k=1,2,…,N). Satisfying boundary conditions (8) on the surfaces of the crack-visible cavity with end domains and pre-fracture zones by the functions (22), (24), we obtain a system of singular integral equations with respect to unknown functions gk(xk) (k=1,2,…,N): (26) Here,
To the system of singular integral equations (26), we should add additional equalities that express the condition of uniqueness of displacements in tracing the contours of crack-visible cavity with end domains and pre-fracture zones (27)

Using the procedure for converting (see Mirsalimov, 1987, appendix) a system to an algebraic system, the system of singular integral equations (26) with additional conditions (27) is reduced to the system of N×M algebraic equations for determining the N×M unknowns gk(tm) (k=1,2,…,N;m=1,2,…,M):(28) where

If we change complexly conjugate quantities in Equation (28), we obtain N×M algebraic equations. The right hand sides of algebraic systems Equation (28) contain unknown values of normal qyn and tangential qxnyn forces at nodal points of appropriate pre-fracture zones and end domains of crack-visible cavity. Using the solution obtained, we find (29)

These complex equations serve to determine the tractions qyk and qxkyk (k=1,2,…,N) of the bonds between the corresponding zone surfaces. For constructing missing algebraic equations for determining approximate values of the tractions, qyk(tm) and qxkyk(tm) (m=1,2,…,M) at the nodal points, we require fulfillment of conditions Equation (29) at the nodal points tm, contained in the end domains and pre-fracture zones. Here, we use the finite difference method. As a result, a complex algebraic system consisting of N×M equations is obtained for determining the quantities qyk(tm), qxkyk(tm) (k=1,2,…,N;m=1,2,…,M) at the nodal points of the end crack-visible cavity and pre-fracture zones. Since the stresses in fuel are restricted, the solution of integral equations is sought in a class of everywhere bounded functions. Such a solution exists when fulfilling the conditions of solvability of integral equations. Therefore, the obtained algebraic systems are not closed yet. For closeness of the obtained algebraic equations, there must be 2×N equations expressing the solvability conditions of integral equations (conditions of stress finiteness in the vicinity of pre-fracture zone vertices xk=±lk(k=1,2,…,N). These conditions have the form (30)

The obtained relations (4), (21), (22), (24), and (28–30) allow us to get terminal solution of the problem if the coefficients αk(k=0,±1,…) will be determined. For composing infinite system of linear algebraic equations with respect to the unknowns αk, allowing (24), we substitute (22) to conditions (13). After some transformations, condition (13) is reduced to the form (31)
Because of the bulky form of expressions for Am,Am*,Um,Um*(m=0,1,2,…) they are not cited here.
Comparing the coefficients with same degrees τ/R and R/τ in both hand sides of the obtained relation (31), we find two infinite systems of linear algebraic equations (32)

The obtained system of equations with respect to gk(tm),qyk(tm), qxkyk(tm)(k=1,2,…,N;m=1,2,…,M), αν(ν=0,±1,…) allow for the given characteristic of bonds to define gas pressure intensity in cavity and stress–strain state of burning fuel in the availability of arbitrary number of pre-fracture zones in fuel.

sec.title: METHOD OF NUMERICAL SOLUTION AND ANALYSIS
sec.p: The following method is convenient for finding numerical solution of these equations: the function p(x1) is sought in the form of a polynomial with unknown coefficients, the equation for p(x1) is satisfied approximately in the sense of the greatest closeness of mean square error to zero. Moreover, the unknown coefficients are determined from the minimum conditions of the obtained function.
The joint resolving system of equations out to be non-linear even in the case of linear elastic bonds due the unknown quantities lk(k=1,2,…,N).

The method of successive approximations is used to solve it. We solve the joint algebraic system for certain specific values of lk*(k=1,2,…,N) with respect to the unknowns αν,gk(tm),qyk,qxkyk. The values of lk* and the found values αν,gk(tm),qyk,qxkyk are substituted into Equation (30) i.e., into unused equations of the joint system. The values of parameters lk* taken and their appropriate values αν,gk(tm),qyk,qxkyk will not, generally speaking, satisfy equations (30). Hence, choosing the values of the parameters lk*, we repeat the calculations many times until equations (30) are satisfied with a specified accuracy. In each approximation, the joint algebraic system of equations was solved by Gauss method with a choice of the principal element for different values of M. In the case of non-linear law of deformation of the bonds, an iterative method is used at the end domains to determine the tractions in the end domains of crack-visible cavity and pre-fracture zones, which is similar to the method of elastic solutions (Il’yushin, 1948). It is assumed that the law of deformation of the interparticle bonds in pre-fracture zones and in the end domains of cavity is linear when V=|(uk+-uk-)-i(υk+-υk-)|≤V*.

The first step of the iterative calculation procedure consists of solving the system of resolving equations for the linear elastic interparticle bonds. Subsequent iterations are only carried out when the inequality V>V* holds in a part of a pre-fracture zone and end domains of cavity. In the case of such iterations, the system of resolving equations is solved for quasi-brittle bonds (cohesive forces) with an effective compliance which is variable along the pre-fracture zone and depends on the magnitude of the modulus of the traction vector in the bonds obtained in the preceding step of the calculation. The effective compliance is calculated in a manner similar to that used to find the secant modulus elastic in the method of variable parameters (Birger, 1965). It is accepted that the successive approximations process is terminated only when the tractions in the zone obtained in two successive steps differ by a small amount. The non-linear part of the curve for the deformation of the bonds was represented in the form of a bilinear relation, the rising part of which corresponded to the elastic deformation of the bonds (0<V(xk)<V*) with maximal tension of the bonds. When V(xk)>V*, the deformation was described by a non-linear relation, which is determined by the two points (V*,σ*) and (δcr,σcr), while when σcr≥σ*, we have an increasing linear relation (linear strengthening corresponding to the elasto-plastic deformation of the bonds).
As it is known (Sorkin, 1967), one of the probable causes of transition of engine to off-design mode in solid fuel is the presence of crack-visible defects on fuel that may lead to unsteady burning.

Instability mechanism is the given as follows. Under definite conditions, velocity of alternation of linear dimensions of cavity in plane may be greater than velocity of change of thickness of cavity. This happens because of local fracture of fuel at the end part of cavity for the reason that there is concentration of stresses and sharp increase of burning velocity at the end of cavity as an effect of local loss of material and increase of combustion surface. The latter is stipulated by local concentration of deformations. Both the physical stability mechanisms are related with the local concentration of deformation. This allows the use of criteria on critical opening of a crack to formulate ultimate equilibrium criterion. Opening of crack-visible cavity faces in the ranges of end domains may be determined by the relations. (33)
Condition of critical opening of crack-visible cavity at the edge of end zone will be (34) where δc is the characteristics of crack resistance of fuel defined experimentally.

Sufficient condition of local stability (safety) of combustion mode of solid fuel will be (35) where x0=λ1 for the left end zone and x0=λ2 for the right end zone. Locally, unstable ‘burning-fracture’ process will start as soon as inequality Equation (35) violates in the small vicinity of appropriate point of crack-visible cavity.

The obtained solution of plane stationary problem allows prediction of appearance of crack-visible cavities in burning solid fuel. For that, it is necessary to supplement the formulation of the problem with a condition (criterion) for the appearance of a cavity (the rupture of the interparticle bonds in the material). As such a condition, we will adopt the criterion for the critical expansion of the pre-fracture zone (36) where δcr is a characteristic of resistance of fuel’s material to cracking.

Using the obtained solution, we can write the limit condition in the form (37) where xk* are the coordinates of the pre-fracture zone points wherein rupture of interparticle bonds in the material occurs.
Below, we consider the approximate calculation assuming that (38) here, A and B are empiric constants.
When calculating displacements and forces in bonds and sizes, of end domains and pre-fracture zones, we will assume that constant pressure (p1+p0)/2 acts on cavity’s wall.
On the base of these simplifications, from the system of equations (4), we will find (39)
p1,ρ1,Vx1,Vx0 are determined from these relations.

Calculation results are shown in Figures 2–4. Figure 2.
Distribution of normal tractions qy1/N0 in the bonds between faces in the end domain from the quantity x1/l1 (curve 1 corresponds to linear law of deformation of bonds and curve 2 to nonlinear deformation). Figure 3.
Dependence of the length of the right end domain d2=(l1-λ2)/l1 on dimensionless value p/N0 for different sizes of crack-visible cavity l*=l01/l1=0,75;0,5;0,3. Figure 4.
Distribution of the maximal value of the modulus of the vector σ1/N0 on relative size of end domain; solid line corresponds to the right end zone and the punctured line to the left end zone of crack-visible cavity.

Graphs of the distribution of normal forces qy1 in bonds for the right end domain of crack-visible cavity (curve 1 for linear bonds and curve 2 for bilinear law of deformation of bonds) are shown in Figure 2.

The law for the change in the tangential tractions along the end domain is similar to the change in the normal tractions with the difference that the absolute values of the tangential tractions are substantially less and the maximal values of the tangential tractions are reached in the case of a zone with smaller dimensions.

Graphs of the dependence of the length of the right end domain d2=(l1-λ2)/l1 on dimensionless value p/N0 for different sizes of crack-visible cavity l*=l01/l1=0,75;0,5;0,3 are shown in Figure 3. A graph of the distribution of the maximal value of the modulus of the vector is shown in Figure 4 as function of the relative size of the end zone.
Here, the solid line corresponds to the right end zone, the punctured line to the left end zone of crack-visible cavity. In all calculations, it was accepted that N=3; α1=450; α2=150; α3=300.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: Thus, a closed system of algebraic equations and local condition of stability of ‘burning-fracture’ mode allowing us to predict ultimately admissible size of crack-visible cavity (technological defect) by numerical calculation for each specific kind of fuel, to take into account influence of damage accumulation in material for opening and growth of crack-visible cavity in burning solid fuel, is constructed.
